Biases Books

Cognitive Biases

Browse the full list of cognitive biases that can affect your decisions

50 biases found

Confirmation Bias

Seeking information that confirms your existing beliefs

Anchoring Bias

Over-relying on the first piece of information received

Sunk Cost Fallacy

Continuing something because of past investments

Halo Effect

Letting one positive trait influence overall judgment

Availability Bias

Overweighting easily recalled information

Overconfidence Bias

Being more confident than accuracy warrants

Status Quo Bias

Preference for the current state of affairs

Affinity Bias

Favoring people similar to yourself

Planning Fallacy

Underestimating time, costs, and risks

Loss Aversion

Feeling losses more strongly than equivalent gains

Hindsight Bias

Believing past events were predictable

Bandwagon Effect

Following the crowd without independent analysis

Recency Bias

Overweighting recent events over historical patterns

Framing Effect

Being influenced by how information is presented

Fundamental Attribution Error

Attributing others\' behavior to character, not circumstances

Optimism Bias

Believing bad things are less likely to happen to you

Pessimism Bias

Expecting negative outcomes even when unlikely

Self-Serving Bias

Taking credit for success, blaming others for failure

Dunning-Kruger Effect

Novices overestimate their competence; experts underestimate

ðŸ§ 

Negativity Bias

Giving more weight to negative experiences than positive ones

Endowment Effect

Overvaluing things because you own them

Gambler\'s Fallacy

Believing past random events affect future probabilities

Authority Bias

Trusting authority figures without questioning

Outcome Bias

Judging decisions by their results, not their quality

Survivorship Bias

Focusing on successes while ignoring failures

Projection Bias

Assuming others share your beliefs and values

Contrast Effect

Judging things based on comparison to adjacent options

Blind Spot Bias

Recognizing biases in others but not in yourself

Hyperbolic Discounting

Preferring immediate rewards over larger future gains

Choice Overload

Being paralyzed by too many options

Spotlight Effect

Overestimating how much others notice you

In-group Bias

Favoring members of your own group

IKEA Effect

Overvaluing things you helped create

Zero-risk Bias

Preferring to eliminate one risk completely over reducing overall risk

Hot-cold Empathy Gap

Underestimating how emotions affect decisions

Decoy Effect

Preferences change when a third option is added

Just-world Hypothesis

Believing people get what they deserve

Base Rate Neglect

Ignoring general statistics in favor of specific information

Illusion of Control

Believing you can influence random or uncontrollable events

ðŸ§ 

Normalcy Bias

Underestimating the possibility of disaster

Naive Realism

Believing your perception of reality is the objective truth

Curse of Knowledge

Difficulty imagining what it\'s like not to know something

Mere Exposure Effect

Preferring things simply because they\'re familiar

Reactance

Doing the opposite when told what to do

Present Bias

Overvaluing immediate rewards over future benefits

Omission Bias

Preferring inaction even when action would cause less harm

Clustering Illusion

Seeing patterns in random data

Moral Licensing

Feeling entitled to bad behavior after doing good

Peak-end Rule

Judging experiences by their peaks and endings, not totals

Effort Justification

Valuing things more because they required effort
